comment.author: 61286047@N00
comment._content:
"In the Heart of the Hibernian Metropolis
BEFORE NELSON'S PILLAR TRAILS SLOWED, SHUNTED, CHANGED TROLLEY, started for Blackrock, Kingstown and Dalkey, Clonskea, Rathgar and Terenure, Palmerston park and upper Rathmines, Sandymount Green, Rathmines, Ringsend and Sandymount Tower, Harold's Cross. The hoarse Dublin United Tramway Company's timekeeper bawled them off:

-- Rathgar and Terenure!

-- Come on, Sandymount Green!

Right and left parallel clanging ringing a doubledecker and a singledeck moved from their railheads, swerved to the down line, glided parallel.

-- Start, Palmerston park!"
Ulysses, the Aeolus episode.
I think TRAILS should be TRAMS

comment.author: 99002941@N08
comment._content: Trams bearing advertisements from the 1930s anyway.

comment._content:
Archiseek on those lights: 1920-23 During this period, new rather bizarre looking electric lamps were attached to the swan-neck posts, replacing the earlier globes...1936-39 Huge change is ushered in with this period with a vast amount of lamppost up-rooting on Oâ€™Connell St and the city centre overall. It saw the installation of the cityâ€™s trademark brown, arched, double-headed aggregate concrete lampposts along many major streets including O'Connell St, O'Connell Bridge

So, 1920 to 1939, not much help.

comment.author: 99002941@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Rounded roof  and more rounded front and entrances (against the rather box like entrances on others).

comment.author: 99002941@N08
comment._content: Vehicle with white roof  on the bridge appears to be one of the buses worked by Woods of Blackrock on the route to Dalkey, but the livery seems different so its likely after they amalgamated with several others to form Dublin & Dalkey Buses Ltd in 1932.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] What an outstanding shot of the iconic bridge and set of junctions!  This is a feast for the eyes between fashions, trams, buses and posters/advertisements!  Well chosen Carol.
 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] You've fairly tied it in to the 7 years of the buses life then, well done!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Thank you, Mr! And [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] plus others are spot on according to this teaser... From the Irish Times of Monday, 18 April 1932: <blockquoteOLD FILMS MADE NEW. Soon Dublin will have a chance to weep again over the sentimental "Over the Hill", which has been re-made as a "talkie", and it is reported that anohter batch of old films is being re-made into "talkies". Included in this latest lot are the Paramount, "The Ten Commandments"; M.G.M.'s "The Big Parade", and "The Merry Widow", with Ramon Navarro and Jeanette MacDonald playing the leading parts; Tallulah Bankhead and Gary Cooper are to lead in "Blood and Sand" for Paramount...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: From "PUBLIC AMUSEMENTS" in the Irish Times of Friday, 20 May 1932: CORINTHIAN CONTINUOUS TODAY FROM 12 NOON TILL 11.0 P.M. The Talking Screen's Newest Stars in their Latest Triumph. JAMES DUNN, SALLY EILERS in "OVER THE HILL" With MAE MARSH and JAMES KIRKWOOD Greater than the Famous Silent Picture! This was still running at the Corinthian on Saturday, 4 June 1932! So May-June 1932... Huzzah!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: What a wonderfully clean image. It always strikes me with old photographs that the space looks enormous by present day standards. The only solution I can think of is that we are now so much more crowded. Maybe look at this scene at 05.00 on  summers morning.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: It's a sunny day, and we can see the  shadows. We can see the direction of the wind from the flags and the smoking chimney. And we can see the state of the tide. All it needs is someone to correlate tide tables, weather reports and shadow-length calculations and it should be easy to narrow down the date. (I'd love to but ...)

comment._content: Can anyone make sense of that road sign (see title) "STRAIGHT ON OR LEFT OR RIGHT TO WESTMORELAND STREET ONLY"?  I had a squizz at GoogleMaps and it makes no sense to upside-down me.  No wonder that poor car is driving the wrong way.

comment.author: 79549245@N06

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] The No 15 tram is also going in the ‘wrong’ direction.  Evidently the traffic island did not mean ‘keep left’, as one would expect, but rather keep left depending on which carriageway you were in!

comment.author: 96261063@N05

"With extremely favourable weather conditions prevailing in the run-up to and during the event"

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
No booze on the day

11.—(1) Notwithstanding anything contained in the Act of 1927, or in any occasional licence, or in any order made under this Act, it shall not be lawful for any person in the Dublin Metropolitan Area or in any part of the County Borough of Dublin which is outside the Dublin Metropolitan Area to sell or expose for sale any intoxicating liquor or to open or keep open any premises for the sale of intoxicating liquor or to permit any intoxicating liquor to be consumed on licensed premises on the 26th day of June, 1932, between the hours of two o'clock and six o'clock in the afternoon.

(2) Every person who shall sell or expose for sale any intoxicating liquor or open or keep open any premises for the sale of intoxicating liquor or permit any intoxicating liquor to be consumed on licensed premises in contravention of this section shall be guilty of an offence under this section and shall be liable on summary conviction thereof to a fine not exceeding twenty pounds.
